sub_topic: Finding the projection of one vector onto another using trigonometry
message_1: A boat is traveling at a speed of 20 km/h and is heading in the direction of 30° East of North. Find the component of its velocity directed due North. (Round your answer to two decimal places.)
message_2:
To find the component of the boat's velocity directed due North, we can use the trigonometric function cosine. The North component of the velocity can be found using the formula:

North component = speed × cos(angle)

where speed is 20 km/h and angle is 30° East of North.

North component = 20 × cos(30°)

First, we need to convert the angle from degrees to radians:

30° × (π/180) = (30 × π) / 180 = π/6 radians

Now, we can find the cosine of the angle:

cos(π/6) ≈ 0.866025

Finally, we can find the North component of the velocity:

North component = 20 × 0.866025 ≈ 17.32 km/h

So, the component of the boat's velocity directed due North is approximately 17.32 km/h.
